commands.name: Step 1: Review Sync Wave Annotations
commands.description: Review all manifests to see their sync-wave annotations
commands.explanation: Each manifest has an argocd.argoproj.io/sync-wave annotation. Resources with lower wave numbers are synced first: ConfigMap (wave -1) -> Deployment (wave 0) -> Service (wave 1). This ensures the ConfigMap exists before the Deployment references it.
commands.what_it_does: Displays all manifests highlighting the sync-wave order.

commands.name: Step 2: Review PostSync Hook
commands.description: Review the PostSync hook Job manifest
commands.explanation: This Job has argocd.argoproj.io/hook: PostSync annotation, meaning it runs AFTER all sync waves complete. The hook-delete-policy: HookSucceeded means the Job is deleted after successful completion. This is useful for running smoke tests or notifications after deployment.
commands.what_it_does: Displays the PostSync hook Job definition.
commands.next_step: Apply the Application CR to start the ordered deployment.

commands.name: Step 3: Apply the Application CR
commands.description: Create the application - watch the ordered sync in ArgoCD UI
commands.explanation: ArgoCD will deploy resources in wave order: first the ConfigMap (wave -1), then the Deployment (wave 0), then the Service (wave 1), and finally the PostSync Job. Open the ArgoCD UI to watch this happen visually.
commands.what_it_does: Creates the Application and triggers ordered deployment.
commands.next_step: Watch the sync waves execute in order.

commands.name: Step 4: Watch Sync Waves in ArgoCD UI
commands.description: Observe the ordered deployment in ArgoCD UI
commands.explanation: In the ArgoCD UI resource tree, you can see the sync progressing through waves. Each wave must complete (resources become healthy) before the next wave begins. This ordering prevents issues like Deployments starting before their ConfigMaps exist.
commands.what_it_does: Guides you to observe sync waves visually in the ArgoCD UI.
commands.next_step: Verify the PostSync hook job ran.
info_steps: Open ArgoCD UI (use the button above)
Watch resources appear in wave order: ConfigMap (wave -1) first, then Deployment (wave 0), then Service (wave 1)
Each wave must complete (become healthy) before the next one begins

commands.name: Step 5: Check PostSync Hook Execution
commands.command: kubectl get jobs -n argocd-sc-03 2>/dev/null && kubectl get events -n argocd-sc-03 --field-selector reason=Completed 2>/dev/null | tail -5
commands.description: Verify the PostSync hook job ran and completed
commands.explanation: The PostSync Job runs after all sync waves complete. Because we set hook-delete-policy: HookSucceeded, the Job is automatically deleted after success. You may see it briefly, or it may already be cleaned up. The events can confirm it ran.
commands.what_it_does: Checks for the PostSync hook Job and related events.
commands.next_step: Verify all resources are deployed in the correct order.

commands.name: Step 6: Verify All Resources
commands.command: kubectl get configmap app-config -n argocd-sc-03 -o yaml 2>/dev/null | head -10 && kubectl get deployment wave-app -n argocd-sc-03 && kubectl get service wave-service -n argocd-sc-03 && kubectl get pods -n argocd-sc-03
commands.description: Verify all resources were created in sync wave order
commands.explanation: All three resources should be present and healthy. The ConfigMap was created first (wave -1) so the Deployment (wave 0) could reference it. The Service (wave 1) was created last after the Deployment pods were running.
commands.what_it_does: Lists all deployed resources to confirm successful ordered deployment.
commands.next_step: Scenario complete! Clean up when ready.

commands.name: Cleanup: Delete Application
commands.command: kubectl delete application sc03-sync-waves -n argocd && kubectl delete namespace argocd-sc-03 --ignore-not-found
commands.description: Remove the ArgoCD application and namespace
commands.explanation: Deleting the Application stops ArgoCD management. The namespace deletion removes all deployed resources including the ConfigMap, Deployment, and Service.
commands.what_it_does: Removes the application and all resources.
